Spin evolution of neutron stars in two modes: implication for
millisecond pulsars
Sudip Bhattacharyya⋆
Department of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Mumbai 400005, India
Accepted 2020 December 30. Received 2020 December 29; in original form 2020 November 26
ABSTRACT
An understanding of spin frequency (ν) evolution of neutron stars in the low-mass X-ray binary (LMXB) phase is
essential to explain the observed ν-distribution of millisecond pulsars (MSPs), and to probe the stellar and binary
physics, including the possibility of continuous gravitational wave emission. Here, using numerical computations we

conclude that ν can evolve in two distinctly different modes, as ν may approach a lower spin equilibrium value (νeq,per)
for persistent accretion for a long-term average accretion rate (Ṁav) greater than a critical limit (Ṁav,crit), and may
approach a higher effective spin equilibrium value (νeq,eff) for transient accretion for Ṁav < Ṁav,crit. For example,
when Ṁav falls below Ṁav,crit for an initially persistent source, ν increases considerably due to transient accretion,

which is counterintuitive. We also find that, contrary to what was suggested, a fast or sudden decrease of Ṁav to
zero in the last part of the LMXB phase is not essential for the genesis of spin-powered MSPs, and neutron stars
could spin up in this Ṁav-decreasing phase. Our findings imply that the traditional way of ν-evolution computation
is inadequate in most cases, even for initially persistent sources, and may not even correctly estimate whether ν
increases or decreases.

1 INTRODUCTION

A rapidly spinning neutron star, with a measured spin
frequency (ν) of ∼

> 100 Hz, is typically known as a mil-
lisecond pulsar (MSP; Bhattacharya & van den Heuvel
1991). Such a star is believed to be spun up in its low-mass
X-ray binary (LMXB) phase, due to the angular momentum
transfer by the matter accreted from the companion donor
star (Radhakrishnan & Srinivasan 1982; Alpar et al. 1982;
Wijnands & van der Klis 1998; Chakrabarty & Morgan
1998; Archibald et al. 2009; Papitto et al. 2013; Bassa et al.
2014). A subset of neutron stars in the LMXB phase are
observed as accretion-powered millisecond X-ray pulsars
(AMXPs; Patruno & Watts 2012; Salvo & Sanna 2020, and
references therein) and nuclear-powered millisecond X-ray
pulsars (NMXPs; Watts 2012; Bhattacharyya 2020a, and
references therein), and after this phase some of the stars
manifest themselves as spin-powered millisecond pulsars
(Bhattacharya & van den Heuvel 1991).

The neutron star spin evolution can happen by accre-
tion related spin-up and spin-down torques and by elec-
tromagnetic (EM) and gravitational wave (GW) spin-down
torques (e.g., Bildsten 1998; Bhattacharyya & Chakrabarty
2017; Haskell & Patruno 2017; Bhattacharyya 2017, 2020b;
Chen 2020). Hence, the observed ν-value distribution of

timescale of ∼ a hundred million years or more. An accreting
neutron star in the LMXB phase spins up and spins down

2 TRANSIENT ACCRETION

Most neutron star LMXBs, including all AMXPs, accrete
matter in a transient manner (Liu et al. 2013; Salvo & Sanna
2020). This results in alternate outburst and quiescent
phases. The former phase lasts typically days to weeks when
Ṁ and the observed X-ray intensity increase by several orders
of magnitude from those in the latter phase, which lasts typi-
cally months to years (e.g., Yan & Yu 2015). These outbursts
of accretion are believed to be caused by two instabilities: the
thermal instability, for which a small increase in the accretion
disc temperature Tdisc causes an additional rise in Tdisc, and

the viscous instability, for which a little increase in Ṁ leads
to a further increase in Ṁ (see Lasota 2001; Done et al. 2007,
and references therein). The timescale of the former instabil-
ity is much less than the timescale of the latter. A thermal
instability could occur for Ṁav < Ṁav,crit (Ṁav,crit is a criti-
cal Ṁav), when due to the accumulation of matter, the Tdisc
value at a certain radius of an initially cold and nonionized
disc exceeds the hydrogen ionization temperature, and hence
the opacity increases by a large amount, photons cannot es-
cape easily anymore, and consequently Tdisc increases sharply.
This triggers the viscous instability, causing a large increase
of Ṁ , and hence an outburst happens. But if Ṁav is suffi-
ciently high (Ṁav > Ṁav,crit), so that Tdisc in the entire disc
always exceeds the hydrogen ionization temperature, the disc
should always be stable, and accretion should happen persis-
tently. Therefore, an initially persistent neutron star LMXB
can become a transient, whenever Ṁav falls below Ṁav,crit.
Particularly, this must happen in the last part (e.g., RLDP)
of the LMXB phase, at the end of which accretion stops. Note
that an expression of Ṁav,crit, considering the X-ray irradi-
ation of the disc, is given by (van Paradijs 1996; King et al.

the same method described in Bhattacharyya & Chakrabarty

3.3 Spin evolution of persistent sources

How does ν evolve for a persistent source? The neutron star
first spins up relatively quickly towards the spin equilibrium
frequency (νeq,per), and then tracks it (see sections 1 and 2,
and Fig. 3). In the RLDP, if Ṁav decreases rapidly, ν de-
creases for a persistent source, but cannot track νeq,per any-
more, which was shown by Tauris (2012), and is confirmed
in Fig. 3. But in reality, a persistent source becomes a tran-
sient for Ṁav < Ṁav,crit, and consequently, ν increases, as it
does not track the lower spin equilibrium frequency νeq,per
anymore, and now approches a higher effective spin equilib-
rium value νeq,eff (see Fig. 3, and also section 2). Therefore,
since even an initially persistent source should become a tran-
sient at least in the RLDP due to the decrease of Ṁav, ν
should increase in this phase (see Fig. 3(b)). The condition
Ṁav < Ṁav,crit can also be satisfied before the RLDP, and
then ν can drastically increase in the pre-RLDP and continue
to increase in the RLDP (see Fig. 3(a)). These are remark-
ably different from the currently believed spin evolution sce-
nario, and to the best of our knowledge, such a possibility

4 DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSIONS

In this Letter, we have demonstrated, for the first time to the
best of our knowledge, that the neutron star spin frequency
ν can approach one of the two spin equlibrium frequencies: a
lower one (νeq,per) for persistent accretion and a higher one
(νeq,eff) for transient accretion. The former is expected to
happen at a higher long-term average accretion rate (Ṁav)
relative to a critical value (Ṁav,crit), and the latter can hap-
pen at a lower Ṁav relative to Ṁav,crit. So there are twomodes
of spin evolution, and the mode leading to the higher ν occurs

typically for lower Ṁav values, which is somewhat counter-
intuitive. While we have shown this with examples of a sud-
den spin-up with a higher rate for a simple transition from
Ṁav > Ṁav,crit to Ṁav < Ṁav,crit (see Fig. 3), an opposite
transition may lead to a sudden spin-down. This gives an idea
of how a complex ν-evolution curve, in which ν evolves by two
alternate modes, may be caused by Ṁav and Ṁav,crit crossing
each other multiple times in the LMXB phase. Even within
the transient accretion regime, ν-evolution may be complex,
if Ṁpeak evolves (section 3.2). This is because νeq,eff evolves
with Ṁpeak (Equation 5), and hence ν approaches an equilib-
rium frequency which may change continuously in a complex
way. For example, depending on the evolution of Ṁpeak, νeq,eff
could evolve to values higher or lower than the ν-value, and
hence ν could increase or decrease, respectively (see section 2
and Fig. 1).

We have also particularly studied the spin evolution in
the RLDP. As mentioned above, in the transient accretion
regime, ν can spin up or spin down depending on the Ṁpeak-
evolution both in the RLDP and before the RLDP. However,
even if ν decreases in the RLDP, it should not decrease con-
siderably (see section 3.2), and such a spin-down is not due to
the previously suggested (see section 1) tracking of νeq,per by
ν. On the other hand, an initially persistent source becomes a
transient at least in the RLDP, as Ṁav sufficiently decreases,
and hence ν should increase, as it now approches a higher
effective spin equilibrium frequency νeq,eff (see section 3.3).
Such a ν-evolution (see Fig. 3) implies that a breaking of ν
from νeq,per and its subsequent decrease in the RLDP (sug-
gested, for example, by Tauris 2012) may not be relevant
in many cases to determine the final ν-value of the LMXB
phase. In fact, ν does not track or approach νeq,per anyway
for transient accretion (see section 2). Therefore, as the Ṁav-
evolution does not determine the ν-evolution, ν should not
attain a low value (e.g., below ∼ 100 Hz), even if Ṁav de-
creases relatively slowly to zero. This implies that, contrary
to what was suggested earlier (see section 1), a fast decrease
of Ṁav in the last part of the LMXB phase is not essential
for the creation of spin-powered MSPs.

Finally, we note that our findings open up possibilities of
many pathways by which ν can evolve, and the traditional
ν-evolution computation (e.g., Tauris 2012) could work only
in special cases, for example, when the source remains per-
sistent till the RLDP, and then Ṁav decreases very rapidly
for Ṁav < Ṁav,crit in the RLDP. The evolution of neutron
stars via two modes due to persistent accretion and transient
accretion should significantly affect ν and other observed pa-
rameter values of MSPs. Such an evolution could be studied
in more detail in the near future using a considerably larger
MSP sample, acquired, for example, by observations with the
Square Kilometre Array (Keane et al. 2015).
